### Project Summary Description

#### 1. Technologies/Measures to be Implemented
The project focuses on the distribution and installation of approximately 500,000 fuel-efficient improved cookstoves (ICS) in Ghana. Specifically, the TLC-CQC Rocket Stoves, with a minimum efficiency of 25%, will replace traditional open fire stoves and three-stone fires prevalent in rural households. The primary goals are to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, conserve forest resources, protect natural ecosystems, and decrease indoor air pollutants. Additionally, the project aims to reduce the time spent collecting wood fuel, thereby easing the workload on rural families. Comprehensive monitoring and data collection procedures will be implemented to ensure transparency and prevent double counting of emission reductions.

#### 2. Location of the Project
The project will be implemented within the geographical boundaries of the Republic of Ghana.

#### 3. GHG Emission Reductions or Carbon Dioxide Removals
The introduction of fuel-efficient improved cookstoves (ICS) is expected to significantly reduce GHG emissions. These ICS units will replace the current practice of cooking on highly inefficient open fire stoves. The improved design of ICS allows for better fuel combustion and more efficient thermal transfer to cooking pots, thereby reducing the amount of wood fuel needed and lowering GHG emissions. The project targets households that currently use inefficient three-stone fires or conventional stoves without improved combustion air supply or flue gas ventilation systems. The methodology "VMR0006: Methodology for Installation of High Efficiency Firewood Cookstoves, Version 1.1" will be applied to calculate the net GHG emission reductions.

#### 4. Scenario Prior to Implementation
Before the project's implementation, the target population primarily relied on non-renewable wood fuel (firewood) to meet their thermal energy needs. The cooking devices in use were predominantly inefficient three-stone fires or conventional stoves lacking improved combustion air supply mechanisms and flue gas ventilation systems. These traditional methods contributed to higher GHG emissions, deforestation, and indoor air pollution.

#### 5. Estimate of Annual Average and Total Reductions and Removals
The project is projected to achieve an average annual GHG emission reduction of 1,126,602 tCO2e. Over the entire crediting period of 10 years, the total reduction is estimated to be 11,266,021 tCO2e.

This comprehensive approach not only addresses environmental concerns but also improves the quality of life for rural households in Ghana by offering a more efficient, safer, and environmentally friendly cooking solution.
